Celebrating Juneteenth is just one step in our ongoing journey toward unity at the University of Iowa.  As we uphold our tradition of a providing welcoming culture for everyone, we recognize there is more we can and will do. 4/4
We donâ€™t celebrate the moment when Black people were declared free from slavery.  We celebrate the moment when the last Black people were actually freed from slavery. 3/4

But, thousands of people living in slavery werenâ€™t made aware of their freedom until Union soldiers arrived in Galveston, TX on June 19, 1865.  For over two and a half years, thousands remained in slavery, despite being freed. 2/4

On June 19, we commemorate the end of slavery in the United States.  On January 1, 1863, President Lincolnâ€™s Emancipation Proclamation officially declared the end of slavery in the United States. 1/4
